quiz.title: Special Inequality Cases
quiz.subtitle: Unit 6 Quiz 8: No Solution and All Real Numbers Cases
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Identifying and Solving Inequalities with No Solution or All Real Numbers as Solutions

questions.question: Solve: $3(x + 2) < 3x + 5$
questions.explanation: Distribute: $3x + 6 < 3x + 5$. Subtract $3x$: $6 < 5$. Since 6 is never less than 5, this is a contradiction, meaning there is No Solution.

questions.question: Solve: $4 - 2(1 - y) \geq 2y + 2$
questions.explanation: Distribute: $4 - 2 + 2y \geq 2y + 2$. Combine like terms: $2 + 2y \geq 2y + 2$. Subtract $2y$: $2 \geq 2$. Since this is always true, the solution is All Real Numbers.

questions.question: Solve: $2(3z - 1) > 6z + 4$
questions.explanation: Distribute: $6z - 2 > 6z + 4$. Subtract $6z$: $-2 > 4$. This statement is false, therefore no value of $z$ will satisfy the inequality.

questions.question: Solve: $5(m + 2) \leq 5m + 10$
questions.explanation: Distribute: $5m + 10 \leq 5m + 10$. Subtract $5m$: $10 \leq 10$. Because 10 is equal to 10, the inequality holds true for All Real Numbers.

questions.question: Solve: $\frac{2x - 1}{3} > \frac{2x + 2}{3}$
questions.explanation: Multiply both sides by 3 to clear the denominators: $2x - 1 > 2x + 2$. Subtract $2x$: $-1 > 2$. This is false, so there is No Solution.

questions.question: Solve: $0.5(4t + 6) \leq 2t + 3$
questions.explanation: Distribute 0.5: $2t + 3 \leq 2t + 3$. Subtract $2t$: $3 \leq 3$. This is an identity, so the solution is All Real Numbers.

questions.question: Which inequality has no solution?
questions.explanation: Subtract $x$ from all options. Only A results in a false statement ($3 < -1$). B and C result in true statements, while D results in $3 \leq -1$, which is also false (Note: ensure only one 'No Solution' exists or clarify distractor D).

questions.question: Solve: $3(2 - w) + 4w \geq 2w + 6$
questions.explanation: Distribute: $6 - 3w + 4w \geq 2w + 6$. Combine: $6 + w \geq 2w + 6$. Subtract $w$: $6 \geq w + 6$. Subtract 6: $0 \geq w$, which is $w \leq 0$.

questions.question: Solve: $2(p - 3) + 4 < 2p - 1$
questions.explanation: Distribute: $2p - 6 + 4 < 2p - 1$. Combine: $2p - 2 < 2p - 1$. Subtract $2p$: $-2 < -1$. Since -2 is indeed less than -1, the solution is All Real Numbers.

questions.question: Which inequality is true for all real numbers?
questions.explanation: $2x + 2 \geq 2x + 1$ simplifies to $2 \geq 1$, which is true. Choice C simplifies to $2 > 2$, which is false.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You recognize special inequality cases: false statements (No Solution) and always true statements (All Real Numbers).
scoreMessages.70: Strong skills! Focus on simplifying completely to see if statement is always true or always false.
scoreMessages.50: Good progress. Practice: 1) Simplify inequality completely, 2) If variables cancel, check resulting statement: true = All Real Numbers, false = No Solution.
scoreMessages.0: Simplify the inequality. If all variables cancel and you get: TRUE statement (like 3 ≥ 2) → All Real Numbers. FALSE statement (like 5 < 2) → No Solution.
